statement.tex: %text Find the value of $x+y$ from the following equation: % 2 \left[\begin{array}{cc} x & 5 \\ 7 & y-3 \end{array}\right]+ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & 2 \end{array}\right]= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 7 & 6 \\ 15 & 14 \end{array}\right]

step.context: \text{Can }2 \left[\begin{array}{cc} x & 5 \\ 7 & y-3 \end{array}\right] \\ %text be rewritten as shown below? %
step.reason: %text Whenwe multiple a matrix by a constant 'k', each entry of the matrix gets multiplied by 'k'. Therefore in our case, % 2 \left[\begin{array}{cc} x & 5 \\ 7 & y-3 \end{array}\right]= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 2x & 10 \\ 14 & 2y-6 \end{array}\right]

step.context: \left[\begin{array}{cc} 2x & 10 \\ 14 & 2y-6 \end{array}\right]+ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & 2 \end{array}\right]= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 7 & 6 \\ 15 & 14 \end{array}\right] \\ %text Will the following equations determine $x$ and $y$? %
step.reason: %text Only matrices of the same order (rows and columns) may be added. We add matrices by simply adding the corresponding elements of two or more matrices. Two matrices are considered equal iff they have the same order and all of their elements are identical. Therefore, % \begin{align} 2x+3&=7 \\ 2y-6+2&=14 \end{align} \implies x+y=2+9=11
